projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Mr. OGILBY's POCKET BOOK OF ROADS With the Computed & Measured Diſtances and the Diſtinction of Market and Poſt Townes
the Third Impreſſion
To which is Added more Roads and Remarkable places omitted in the Former
Allsoe a Table for the Ready, finding any Road & the Diſtance from LONDON
By WILLIAM MORGAN His Majeſty's Cosmographer
LONDON Printed for the Author and Sold at His House next the Blew Boar in Ludgate Street, And by the Seueral Booksellers In LONDON and Weſtminſter &c 1679

div.head: ADUERTISMENT
div.p: WILLIAM MORGAN having ocation to Print a 3d. Impreſſion of this Book of Roads. To make it more Vseful and leſs Chargeable hath added Several Roads and Reduced the price to 8d. in ſheets
The ſheet MAP of England Being fitted to Bind with it, the Price 10d
Sold at his House Next the Blew Boar in Ludgate Street

p.hi: And Whereas Some late Propoſers for Publiſhing an Engliſh Atlas; to Procure Subſcribers. Doe falſly Pretend that Mr OGILBY'S deſign is Laied Aſide &c
THIS is to Giue notice that Wm. MORGAN His Majeſty's Cosmographer doth Prosecute & by Gods Aſiſtance will finiſh Mr. OGILBY's Atlas;
Though he Doth not Publiſh any Propoſalls Nor take Subſcriptions Till he hath it in His Power to A ſure the Adventurers When they ſhall Receive what they Subſcribe for

div.p: There hath been Already Layd out more then 7000 l. on the ſaid work

div.head: BOOKES Sold by Wm. MORGAN
div.p: The Historical & Geographical Discription of Africa, America, Aſia, Japan, & China, all in Royal Folio with MAPS and Seulps
The Actual Survey of England or Britannia Volume the 1st. describing the CITIES and Townes, with all Things Remarkable in the Travelling Part of England and Wales
The Kings Entertainm't in his Paſſage through LONDON to his Coronation
Homers Jlliads & Odyſſes, Virgil, & Eſop in two Volumes all in Royal folio with Sculpturs and Annotations, Also Virgil, and Eſop, in 8o

div.head: MAPS and PRINTS
div.p: The Survey of LONDON Describing the Perticuler Houſes at 100. foot in an Inch

Saxtons England Reuived and Corected with the Addition of Townes, Roads & Tables of diſtance; Latitude & Longitude & Directions for Travailling. Sold alsoe by Mr. CADE at the Globe Near the Royal Exchange

list.item: The ſheet MAP of England with the Roads; the MAPS of Ameriac; Middlesex Kent; & Eſsex; each 1s
The MAPS of the Several Roades Fitted to Bind in A Pocket Book each ſheet 6d
The MAPS of Jamaica; and Carolina; each 9d
The MAP of Maryland and Bar-bados each 6d
The Prints of Adam & Eve & Solomons Temple; each 9 d
The Prospect of Jerusalem; in two ſheets 1 s. 6d
The Prospect of Edenborough in two ſheets 1 s. 6d
The Ground Plot and Prospect of Canterbury; 1s
The Ground Plot of Kings Linn & Tangier; each 6d

div.p: A Table of the Principal Townes and their diſtance from London &c.

The Numbers vnder C is the Computed diſtance vnder M.F. the measure by Miles and furlongs, for Example againſt Barwick vnder C.M.F. you have 262-339, 2 that is to say from London to Barwick is by Computation 262. miles by measure it is 339. miles and 2 Fur. The figure before the name directs you to fol: 2 where you have the Road to Barwick & the diſtance of each Town and soe of the Reſt
A Table of the Croſs Roads and the diſtance of the several Cities and Towns from those in Capitals
As from Briſtol to Bath and all the Towns till you come to Brandon, then the following Towns take their diſtance from Brandon till you come to Bridgwater and soe of the Reſt

div.head: EXPLANATION.
div.p: IN each Road you have, 1ſt. named the Place whence, and to which the Road goeth, as Number 1. from London to Aberiſtwith, and in the Croſs Roads, Cambridg to Coventry, &c. then follows the Names and perticular Diſtance of each Remarkable Place you paſs.
The Numbers under C. ſhews you the Vulgar Computation, the Numbers under M. F. gives you the Meaſured Diſtance by Miles and Furlongs.

And by caſting up the Numbers you have the diſtance of any one Town from another as fol 1. No 1. from London to Stoken-church you will find it by computation 35 miles & by Meaſure 39 mile 2 furl of which 8. makes a mile, & ſo of the Reſt.
But we haue given you the Totalls of the Computation and Meaſure of each Road with the Cities and Market Townes thereon, in the foregoing Tables

Where the Computation is omitted or that Town is not a mile from the Next admits of ſome odd parts, of a Mile & in ſuch caſes we have given the Computed Diſtance from the Town before to the Town following the Omittion.

As in the Roads to Aberiſtwith, from Kenſington Gravel-pits to Shepheards-Buſh, it is by Meaſure 1. Mile 7. Furllongs but the Computation is omitted till you come to Acton, which is accounted 3. miles from Kenſington Gravel-pits.
We have Devided the Roads under Two Heads, Roads from London, and Croſs Roads.

In the Roads from London there are divers that go part of the Way, and then turn out of the great Roads; & to avoid Repeating the Towns and their Diſtances, till you come to the place where you leave the great Road, you are Referred to the Read out of which each Branch Iſſues.

As in the Road from London to Buckingham you are directed to Number 1. for the Way as far as Uxbridg, and in the Road from London to Montgomery, you are Referred to Number 1. for the Way as far as Worceſter, where the Road to Aberiſtwith and the Road to Montgomery part, and ſo of the Reſt.

The Croſs Roads are ſuch as Lead from one City or great Town to another, and have no Repetition or Reference: they are placed Alphabetically where the Town that begins the Road takes place, as the Town that ends the Road doth in those from London, but the Tables direct you readily to find either.

For Diſtinction Cities are in CAPITALS, Market-Towns in Italique, and Poſt-Towns markt thus * as Page 1. * Waltham-Croſs is a Poſt and not a Market-Town, Hodſdon is a Market and not a Poſt-Town, * Ware is both Market and Poſt, &c.
